agents_response: The hypotenuse of the right triangle is twice the length of the shorter leg, which is $2 \cdot 6=12$ units. The side of the equilateral triangle is therefore 12 units long. The distance from any vertex of an equilateral triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side is $\sqrt{3}/2$ times the length of the side. So, the distance between the two vertices that the triangles do not have in common is the sum of the lengths of two such distances, or $2 \cdot (\sqrt{3}/2) \cdot 12 = \boxed{12\sqrt{3}}$ units.
